# Agni-III

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

_Agni-III_  
---  
Type | [Intermediate Range Ballistic Missile](/wiki/Intermediate_Range_Ballistic_Missile "Intermediate Range Ballistic Missile")  
Place of origin | India  
Service history

**Agni-III** is an [intermediate-range ballistic missile](/wiki/Intermediate-
range_ballistic_missile "Intermediate-range ballistic missile") developed by
[India](/wiki/India "India") as the successor to [Agni-II](/wiki/Agni-II
"Agni-II").[6] It has a range of 3,500 km- 5,000 km,[11] and is capable of
engaging targets deep inside neighbouring countries,[12] including Shanghai in
China.[13] The missile’s [Circular error
probable](/wiki/Circular_error_probable "Circular error probable") (CEP) is
within 40 meters range, which makes it the most sophisticated and accurate
ballistic missile of its range class in the world.[14] In June 2011, it was
reported that Agni-III has been inducted into the armed forces and is under
production.[15] [US Air Force](/wiki/US_Air_Force "US Air Force") [National
Air and Space Intelligence
Center](/wiki/National_Air_and_Space_Intelligence_Center "National Air and
Space Intelligence Center") estimates that as of June 2017 less than 10
launchers were operationally deployed.[16]

## Introduction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-III&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Introduction")]

India's [Credible minimum deterrence](/wiki/Credible_minimum_deterrence
"Credible minimum deterrence") envisages a [nuclear triad](/wiki/Nuclear_triad
"Nuclear triad") of counter-strike capability which required a long range
missile to provide robust [second strike](/wiki/Second_strike "Second strike")
capability. A missile system that can be dispersed far and wide in the Indian
mainland, its far flung islands or its blue water naval assets dispersed
across the world's oceans. Following this necessity India developed a larger
Agni-III missile, with a heavier payload and a longer range but in a compact
configuration, i.e. thicker but shorter length. This development is driven by
need for a more assured retaliation that can defeat emerging [anti ballistic
missile](/wiki/Anti_ballistic_missile "Anti ballistic missile") (ABM) defence
and countermeasures. Such capability requires a compact missile that can also
carry ABM counter-measure payloads along with weapons, in a configuration
similar to a [MIRV](/wiki/MIRV "MIRV"), albeit with state-of-the-art decoys.
The Deputy Project director who was responsible for the writing of the user
handbook manual was Lieutenant Colonel Rajeev Sharma.[17]

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-III&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Description")]

Agni III was developed as the successor to [Agni-II](/wiki/Agni-II "Agni-
II").[6] Designed by the [Indian government's](/wiki/Government_of_India
"Government of India") [Defence Research and Development
Organisation](/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Organisation "Defence
Research and Development Organisation"), Agni III is a [two-
stage](/wiki/Multistage_rocket "Multistage rocket") [ballistic
missile](/wiki/Ballistic_missile "Ballistic missile") that is capable of
[nuclear weapons delivery](/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_delivery "Nuclear weapons
delivery"). It was designed and developed by the Advanced Systems Laboratory
(ASL),[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] a unit of DRDO, which was formed in September 2001 with its main
objective being the development of large-sized rocket motors. ASL developed
the propulsion plant for solid-fuel motors, including the infrastructure for
propellant casting. The stubby two-stage solid fuel missile is compact and
small enough for easy mobility and flexible deployment on various surface/sub-
surface platforms.[18]

The missile is equipped with sophisticated navigation, guidance and control
systems along with advanced on-board computer systems. The electronic systems
are hardened for higher vibration, thermal and acoustic effects. A high
performance indigenous ring laser gyro-based navigation system was flight-
tested for the first time during the Agni-III trial on 7 Feb 2010.[19]

The Agni-III has two stages with an overall diameter of two meters. Initially,
the first stage mass was about 32 tonnes and 7.7 m long, the second stage mass
was about 10 tonnes and 3.3 m long. The missile is likely to support a wide
range of [warhead](/wiki/Warhead "Warhead") configurations, with a 4,500 km
range and a total payload weight of 2490 kg.[6]

## Weight reduction and missile redesign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-
III&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Weight reduction and missile
redesign")]

DRDO carried out extensive technological enhancement to enhance the
performance and to reduce the weight of the Agni-III missile system and to
achieve this the entire system was redesigned including the use of [maraging
steel](/wiki/Maraging_steel "Maraging steel") and a composite motor rocket.
The weight of the Agni-III missile has been reduced to 22 tonnes.[3]

## Propulsion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-III&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Propulsion")]

The Agni-III features two [solid fuelled](/wiki/Solid_rocket "Solid rocket")
stages and with overall diameter of 2.0 meters. This diameter is compatible
with a recently tested Indian sub-surface launch system, which has a 2.3 meter
diameter launch tube aperture.

The first stage booster is made of advanced carbon composite materials to
provide high [payload fraction (mass fraction)](/wiki/Payload_fraction
"Payload fraction"). It is 7.7 meters long, with a diameter of 2 metres. The
second stage made of maraging steel and has a length of 3.3 metres. The second
stage has [vectoring nozzles](/wiki/Vectoring_nozzles "Vectoring nozzles"), to
provide necessary flight trajectory control.

## Maneuvering re-entry vehicle Agni RV Mk 4[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-
III&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Maneuvering re-entry vehicle Agni RV
Mk 4")]

Agni-III supports a wide range of weapons, with total payload weight ranging
from ~600 kg to 1,800 kg including decoys and other ABM countermeasures.
Instead of conventional bus architecture, the RV (Re-Entry Vehicle) is self-
contained with velocity correction package, [navigation](/wiki/Navigation
"Navigation") and [re-entry](/wiki/Re-entry "Re-entry") control
systems.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The lighter and tougher RV body has an all-carbon composite re-entry heat
shield with multi-directional carbon re-entry nose tip and control surfaces.
The new lightweight composites can withstand temperatures of up to 6000
degrees Celsius, and are capable of greater re-entry velocity.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## K-4 SLBM[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-III&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: K-4 SLBM")]

Main article: [K-4 (SLBM)](/wiki/K-4_\(SLBM\) "K-4 \(SLBM\)")

The K-4 missile is one of the series of missile developed under the [K-X
series](/wiki/K_Missile_family "K Missile family").[20] DRDO is working on a
submarine-launched version of the Agni-III missile, which will provide India
with a credible sea-based second-strike capability.[21] The K-4 missile, with
a range of 3500 km, has been test-fired successfully multiple times-both from
underwater pontoons and from INS Arihant. The K-4 SLBM is expected to be the
principal intermediate range missile for the Arihant class nuclear submarines.
An as-yet unnamed variant of K-4 with 5000 km range is under development.[22]

## Flight tests[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Agni-III&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Flight tests")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Agni_missile_range.svg/220px-
Agni_missile_range.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Agni_missile_range.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Agni_missile_range.svg "Enlarge")

Agni missile range

The first test for Agni III was conducted from [Abdul Kalam
Island](/wiki/Abdul_Kalam_Island "Abdul Kalam Island") (then known as Wheeler
Island) off the [Bhadrak](/wiki/Bhadrak "Bhadrak") coast on 9 July 2006.[6]
The launch proved to be unsuccessful, with the missile falling into the sea
off the coast of [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha "Odisha"), short of reaching the
target. According to [DRDO](/wiki/DRDO "DRDO"), the failure was due to a first
stage anomaly that was caused by recirculating hot gases entering the missile-
base shroud and damaging the electronic components.[23] Indian Defence
Minister [Pranab Mukherjee](/wiki/Pranab_Mukherjee "Pranab Mukherjee")
reported it as "partial success" (a trade euphemism to indicate the test
generated useful data for diagnosis and correction) as the missile was air-
borne for only 5 minutes instead of the expected 15 minutes.[24]

Agni-III was test fired again on 12 April 2007, from the Abdul Kalam Island
off the coast of Odisha. This time, the launch was declared as a success.
India's [Cabinet Committee on Security](/wiki/Cabinet_Committee_on_Security
"Cabinet Committee on Security") announced that[25] "This test confirms the
extent of India's nuclear reach and India's [nuclear
deterrence](/wiki/Nuclear_deterrence "Nuclear deterrence") as the missile can
accurately hit targets at distance more than 3000 km away".[26]

Already the most powerful and capable in India's missile inventory, the Agni-
III is capable of carrying a variety of warheads, including nuclear warheads
and can be launched from various platforms giving India intermediate range
ballistic missile firepower and greatly extending India's [power
projection](/wiki/Power_projection "Power projection") in the region.[27][28]

Agni III was test fired successfully for third time on 7 May 2008.[29] The
missile was launched from Balasore, Odisha.[30] After a flight of roughly 15
minutes defence scientists confirmed that the test fire was successful and
that the missile met all parameters. The missile has a velocity of 5,000
meters per second. Agni-III is a nuclear capable fully solid propellant
fuelled surface-to-surface missile, and has a range of 3,500 km. A new
software for navigation system fitted on the missile will increase accuracy
and lethality.[31] The successful test on 7 May opened the doors for the next
generation Indian ICBM Agni V with a range of 5,000–6,000 kilometres.[32]

The development test of Agni III was put off for unknown reasons in August
2009.[33]

Agni III was tested successfully for the fourth time from Abdul Kalam Island
in Odisha on 7 February 2010. The missile is said to have hit the target with
pin point accuracy and met all the mission objectives. Two down range ships
located near the target tracked and witnessed the Missile reaching the target
accurately.[34] The missile is likely to support a wide range of warhead
configurations, with a 3,500 km range and a total payload weight of 2490
kg.[7] The two-stage solid fuel missile is compact and small enough for easy
mobility and flexible deployment on various surface/sub-surface platforms. The
test validated the nuclear triggering mechanism, meaning Agni-III is meant for
strategic nuclear deterrence.[7] The test launch is part of pre-induction of
the missile into the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army").[35]

In August 2010, the defence minister of India announced that Agni-III is ready
for induction[36] and in June 2011, it was reported that the Agni-III missile
had already been inducted into the armed forces.[15]

In September 2012, it is reported that a missile group is now being raised
with Agni-III missiles.[37]

On 21 September 2012, as part of regular user-training the [Strategic Forces
Command](/wiki/Strategic_Forces_Command "Strategic Forces Command") test fired
an Agni III missile from a rail mobile launcher. The missile was randomly
chosen from a production lot. All mission objectives were achieved and the
missile hit the pre-designated target with a two-digit accuracy.[38]

On 23 December 2013, the missile was tested by the Strategic Forces Command of
the Indian Army. The test was a success.[39]

On 16 April 2015, Agni-III was tested successfully from Abdul Kalam Island off
Odisha coast. "The trial, carried out by the Strategic Forces Command (SFC of
the Indian Army), was fully successful," ITR Director M V K V Prasad told
PTI.[40]

On 27 April 2017, Agni-III was tested successfully the launch Pad No. 4 of the
Integrated Test Range at 9.12 a.m off Odisha coast. The Strategic Forces
Command (SFC) carried out test with support from DRDO.[41][42]
